Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 01:30AM Jule wrote: Lanef, I am so sorry to hear about your mom. My thoughts and prayers are with you and your family. Julie
Posts.Title: MY MOM IS NOW AN ANGEL...AND I ALREADY MISS HER! LANEF SandyAust

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 08:30PM Jule wrote: Hi. I bought a wig from TLC, and I hated it only because it was all sewn by machine so that it looks like there is no part. I went to a wig shop and got a wig for around 400.00. The woman there was wonderful, and I also brought a good friend of mine who makes me laugh to pick one out. She trimmed it for me, and she really made it look like me. I have received tons of compliments about the wig....people think it is my own hair. That being said....I wear it only to work, restaurants, or to church. Otherwise at home...bare. Outside, shopping, ball game, I wear ball caps or a skull cap. As soon as I walk in my house from work, I take off the wig. It is so hot during the summer and I hate wearing it. But it looks real, it really isn't uncomfortable, and I don't worry about what others think when  I wear it. I miss my own hair. My big suggestion is to cut your hair shorter if your hair is long before you start chemo or right after you start. Once it starts falling out, it comes out in clumps which is really hard to deal with. I cut it very short after it started doing this, and then a couple of days later had my sil shave it for me. It was hard, but I was glad that I was in control of when my hair came out. Good luck to you....it is a difficult part of the process or at least for me it was.
Posts.Title: Share the details of your wig with me? Drea angie27

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 09:05PM Jule wrote: Hi Deb. I am on 4 of 6, and I have to say glad that you posted this. I thought that no one else was doing TAC! I think the thing to consider is if you plan on working, and then try to arrange your schedule around this. My onc had me go on thur the first time, but then I felt horrible on the following Monday and 1/2 tuesday. I now have tx on Wed, work Thur and Friday. Sleep all day Sat and Sund with meals, and then start rebounding Mon pm. So I am only taking the extra Monday off. That being said it does have a cumulative effective, and the more txs the harder it hits. The fatigue is what bothers me the most, but after the full week...you start to fill so much better and normal which is awesome! I think that is the thing to remember, that all of the s.e. are temporary and they will go away. I was terrified the first time as I could not concentrate on anything, but that was also due to a lack of sleep due to the steriods. Be sure to get something to sleep. The taste sensations is disgusting because it tastes like you have been sucking on metal constantly....but that does go away as well. EAting with plastic forks/spoons also helps. I didn't get a choice by my onc...told this was the most aggressive tx and needed because of sister death to bc, age, and family history with cancer, as well as the grade, and lymph node. Best of luck with your decision....it is a difficult journey anyway that you go but it is good to know that you do everything that you can.
Posts.Title: TAC treatment??? Help! Passenger59 BikerChick

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 04:59AM Jule wrote: Prayinghands, Did you have the biopsy yet? It sounds like the recommendations is for a biopsy at this point because of the BI-RADS. This just means that the areas are suspicious. Most (over 80%) turn out to be benighn.....It sounds like the area is about 2 cm in size based on what you said. You should hear your results back in a couple of days if you had the biopsy. My thoughts and prayers are with you....I hope you hear great news!
Posts.Title: newbie prayinghands lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 05:01AM Jule wrote: Hi. I started rads this week. I have had 4 now only 32 left. I was diagnosed in April, had chemo (TAC) until Sept every 3 weeks, and had a bilateral masectomy Sept 25. I started Zoladex (I think) and will start Tamoxifen after rads. My scar has swollen a bit and it is more tended where before there was no sensation (after 3 rads). I don't have any tattoos but lots of marker lines all over my body which they touch up every session. I haven't gotten any creams or anything....I have a meeting with the rad onc next week. I am counting down....I was hoping to be done with all of this before January, but now it seems like I will be doing this through the beginning of January.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 09:39PM Jule wrote: I used Aquaphor and I think it was horrible. I like the Aveno for severly dry skin. Start using it now! Good luck - it will seem like forever in some ways but it really is pretty quick. Everyone's skin is different so I hope that yours (07508125) does well with the rads.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 09:33PM Jule wrote: Zuffa, I had chemo this summer - TAC once every 3 weeeks for 6 sessions. I had it on Wednesdays and took the whole day off. I then worked Thursday and Friday. Saturday, Sunday, Monday and sometimes Tuesdays I was off. I was exhausted and slept the whole time but I could get through the 1st days after chemo.  I think that you will have to see how your body does with the combination of drugs and what will work for you. You can work, just be prepared to be a little more tired so be sure to sleep or get medicine to help you sleep if you can't.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Working During Chemo zuffa kjbell

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 08:37PM Jule wrote: Oldlady, The whole process is so difficult! I know that I am to have surgery in October, and I am doing my best to not think about it yet. Like you I nursed my 2 kids. Everything was purely functional, and I certainly wouldn't mind a reduction. At this point I am having a bilateral, but i really am scared about how I will look at what my dh will think. I know that ultimately it is about living as long as I can with less fear of recurrence, but it really is scary. Are you planning on having reconstruction?
Posts.Title: Wrong priorities oldlady susan_02143

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 07:08PM Jule wrote: Julie, Check to see what the hospital says regarding the surgery. I had to have someone drive my because of the anasthesia from the surgery....the surgery was early in the morning, but I don't think that I got out until 3 that afternoon. I have some problem with anasthesia so perhaps that is why. My blood pressure always drops after having it. Anyway I would call and ask to be sure. I was very tired when I left. Are you getting a port at the same time?  I did not get the cream, and so definitely ask. It hurts for a couple of minutes without it, but it does go away. Good luck on your surgery...hoping that nodes are all negative for you:)

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 06:29AM Jule wrote: I have had 1 tx and I am working. I have to say it depends on the schedule for chemo and side effects that she might have. That being said she might want to coordinate with her doctor regarding dates for chemo. I originally had it for Thursdays every 3 weeks, but I recently changed it to Wednesdays so that I would feel worse on Saturday and Sunday and probably only need Wednesday for treatment and the following Monday off. That being said everyone is different and she might have different side effects. It really depends on the drugs that she is given as well. Good luck and best wishes to you and your mom. She will need your support.

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 08:04PM Jule wrote: Mela4409, My hair started falling out around day 16 or 17. When it started coming out, it came out in clumps. I think one bad thing was that I kept waiting for it fall out and I was driving myself crazy feeling my head to see if anything was missing. I also had a tightness in my head which hurt until it fell out. I went to get my wig, and the woman cut it quite a bit shorter while I was there. I ended up cutting the rest of it off in about 4 days after that.  Good luck with your treatment. It will get better - it just feels rough right now.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 03:37PM Jule wrote: Sue, Glad to hear that you are doing well. Regarding the metallic taste, brush your teeth often and I avoided metal silverware for about a week. It really did help eating with plastic. Sometimes it takes a couple of days to really effect you....I usually was exhausted on the 3rd day after chemo, and it usually lasted for about 3 days. However I was on TAC...every regiment is different. Good luck to you...it sounds like you have a supportive family to help you.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 09:43AM Jule wrote: I would call and ask them what you should bring. I know that I was encouraged to bring food and drink. I was also there from 9:30 until 4:30. Be sure to drink lots during chemo. I read somewhere that you should be careful what you eat as you might not want to eat it again. I ate a chopped chicken salad, and now I can't stand to eat a salad or grilled chicken. I thought it was odd until I spoke with someone going through chemo and she said that she felt the same way. Good luck. My 2nd tx is next Wednesday.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 06:27AM Jule wrote: First tx yesterday...long day 9 - 4:30. It was okay but so long. I was glad that my husband went with to take notes about everything. Got home, tired and stomach hurt. Up since 4....mind is a little fuzzy I think from getting up to pee all night. I felt like I was pregnant again:) Tina, I also brought a rag magazine to the place. I actually did feel a little bad when the nurse came over as I was literally the youngest one there until probably the end.  I would tuck it away and then bring it back out when she left. Too silly huh?  Most of the people were in their 70s and 80s, and they sounded so bad. They put me in the corner which was nice to just get used to everything. Hope you are doing good today. Julie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 07:54AM Jule wrote: Hi. Like some of you Thursdays are my day as well. The first tx went okay...just long. Went to work yesterday....fuzzy but okay. I could definitely feel energy drops....shaky at time. I did get my hair cut last night. At my shoulders and now it is at my chin level. So short...hasn't been this short for about 22 years....but baby it's getting shorter huh? I did the 3000 shot last night which was fine but a little worrisome. I was so busy trying to read the direction and do the shot it was kind of crazy. I thought I was going to mess it up! I can't remember who was asking about insomnia...but I take Benadryl at night. It knocks me out and 2 tablets are better than 1 unless I am exhausted. Otter, thanks for the graph. It makes sense. My rbc was at 10.9 and I know they prefer 10 at the lowest (at least I think that's right). I have always been on the low side, and so I am a bit worried about it. It sounds like I will be feeling that more around day 9 or 10 right? Have a good weekend everyone. Stay strong.....it might actually be in the 80s here in IL.....since we have been in the 50s. Maybe we are going to catch a break with the warmer weather this weekend.

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 12:13AM Jule wrote: Otter, congrats on being done. I can't wait until I get to that point. Desi, it will get better. As the other posts said, drink lots of water, eat lots or protein (peanut butter), etc. Also make sure you are resting enough,  and if you aren't getting enough sleep, talk with your doctor about getting something. After my first tx, I felt bad on the Sunday through Tuesday after even though my treatment was on Thursday. I talked with my doc and she said that will probably continue to be how I feel, and we actually changed the date to Wed so that I will feel worse on the weekend so that I can go to work on the Tuesday after most probably. Hopefully this works.   Day 14 today, and I am worried about my hair. My hair/head feels a little odd and I am having trouble sleeping. I am actually worried that I will wake up with hair all over. Is that crazy? Like others I am starting to notice other people's hair. I work in downtown Chicago, and yesterday 4 of the approx 100 people I saw walking to work were bald and all men.  KristyAnn, I have a cousin going through chemo and she advised taking 3-4 Ibuprofen before the Neulasta shot to reduce bone pain. I am going to try it before my next shot next Thursday, and so hopefully it works.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 07:55PM Jule wrote: Desi, I hope that your doc saw you today. I have a cousin who is going through chemo and she had the same response as yours. The docs kind of dismissed her, and she has not had complications from her lungs because of the chemo drugs. It was pretty rare that happened since she had only dx before it started. Just be careful, and if it continues be sure to follow up with the doc. She ended up in the hospital a couple of times, and they had to change her chemo meds. Eddie, that is crazy. Why don't they let you take the IV pole with you? And thanks for bringing up the hair issue...I am going through the same thing. My hair looks like crap though....kind of dead and lifeless so to speak:)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 12:02PM Jule wrote: Otter, I am sorry to hear about stuff with your mom. I kind of feel the same way, but I think sometimes people will say stuff because they really want it to work out well for you and so if they say oh it will be fine, it will be.  Not that it makes you feel any better. My MIL said to me last weekend, oh my brother said your hair isn't that short. Seriously about 2 inches long and it used to go to past my shoulders. It was odd...and why tell me. Other people said well you're haircut will be so cool for the summer. Sure it will be cool for another 3 or 4 days until all of my hair falls out!  Whatever. I did tx 2 on Wednesday and it was okay. A little more nauseous and severely bloated....I guess all the saline. Don't really know. However better in that I knew what I was getting you know? I knew I would be a little buzzy and fuzzy which was so much better than not knowing.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 12:18AM Jule wrote: I don't know if you can take the test actually or rather that your insurance would cover it. If one of your sisters took the test and it is negative, chances are that they would not approve it. My sister passed awat from bc in 2001 and I was diagnosed April 2008. I took the test and it came out negative. My other sister went to the doctor and after talking to a genetic counselor the recommendation was that she did not need to take the test as it was negative for me. Now, they do think that there are some other type of genetic issues, but they don't have the research to say what other gene to look at. I don't know; it's frustrating. Good luck with your family!

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 09:54AM Jule wrote: Hi Joanne. Sorry to hear of your news. Just know that you can get through this. Regarding hair loss everyone is different. My onc said from the very beginning that it would be about 15 days after the treatment that my hair would start falling out. She was right - it came out more in the shower when it was wet. I did get my hair cut shorter before this point (I had shoulder length hair to start.) which helped. For me it started itching, and then my scalp hurt. It felt like someone was pulling on my hair. However acetemenphen(sorry spelling is out today).  I did go to a very good wig place and found an awesome wig that was similiar to my newer haircut. But I also use hats, scarves, and go bald. It just depends on where I am and who I am with. Good luck and lots of ((((((((hugs)))))))))))

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 07:51PM Jule wrote: Bettelou, I had SNB on a Monday, and I was back at work on Wednesday. I think that I was more out of it because of the anesthesia more than anything else on Tuesday.  Wednesday I was back doing fine although I had some difficulty with the tape. Be on the watch of the tape, and it is bothering you be sure to call the office. I had blisters from the tape which the surgeon's office reported was not uncommon. So just be watchful....it might save you some pain. BTW...I was never allergic to tape before this.  Anyway the SNB is not too bad and you should be okay. Good luck with this and with your job.

Recovery time should not be affected because of this. Good luck!
